text:
Excellent, everything a true lemon bar should be. Buttery, tender and tart.  Definitely use at least 1/2 cup of lemon juice or more.  I've made this recipe many times and find that 2/3 cups lemon juice (juice of 3 large lemons) gives this the perfect tartness. (add 1 extra tablespoon flour if using 2/3 cup juice)  I also added the zest of 2 of the lemons.  I made this in an 8 X 11 dish (smaller than what the recipe calls for) and found it ideal.  The crust is the perfect thickness and there is enough lemon custard in each bite to satisfy.  This recipe makes a lot of crust and does spread into a 9 x 13 dish easily, but makes a thinner bar.  If using the smaller baking dish (i.e, 8 X 11), make sure to increase cooking time of the crust and filling an extra 5-10 min each.  As another reviewer stated, it's better to overcook then undercook the crust.  Also, add 1/4 teaspoon salt to the crust for more flavor.  This will be my master recipe for Lemon Bars.

text:
I have made two other recipes of lemon bars and on both of them the end result was that the liquid filling kind of melted in with the crust. On this recipe however, you can see a nice shortbread crust that was about 1/4 inch thick and 1/4 inch of the filling on top of that. I increased the lemon juice by one more large lemon and got about 3/4 of a cup of lemon juice. I also zested two of the lemons and added that to the liquid filling before cooking. I love it super tart, but I think most people might like it better a little less, so I would suggest using 1/2 cup of fresh squeezed lemon juice. Also,I let the crust cool for until it was just room temperature. To speed this up I put it in front of a fan for about 15 min. and it worked great. Then when the crust was cooled down I poured the liquid filling over it. I cooked the crust first for 20 min. then when  returned it to the oven with the filling, I cooked it for about 25 min. I ate some after it came out of the oven, but about 4 hours later, after being in the fridge, they were the perfect consistency. A nice firm crust, and the filling was like a really firm pudding that held its shape. I also added a teaspoon of salt to the crust recipe. I made mine in a 9 x 12 pan. Next time I am going to double the recipe so that the crust is thicker and their is a thicker amount of filling on top.

text:
As printed, this recipe was not lemony enough.  Using other's suggestions, I tried it again using the juice of 5 lemons (a little over 2/3 cup) and the zest of two lemons. I also added 1/3 c. flour to compensate for the extra liquid.  I also had to increase the bake time to about 24 minutes.  These turned out GREAT with the extra lemon (and, of course, powdered sugar on top).  I also added a dash of salt to the crust and thought it was divine.  These weren't anything flashy or out of the ordinary...just exactly what lemon bars should taste like.

text:
I hate it when folks don't try and then rate the original recipe.  Having said that, I'm forced to live a double standard and do just that!  I wanted to give Patty 5 stars for a perfect base recipe to start from.  After reading reviews, i just knew that Patty's original recipe wasn't going to have enough filling, nor be lemony enough to satisfy my lemon craving.  So here are the small changes I made to quell the lemon monster:  kept shortbread recipe as is, but added 1 tsp lemon zest.  Doubled the filling recipe, using a total of 1 1/4 cups fresh squeezed lemon juice and added an extra 2 Tbsp flour.  Cooked crust to recipe instructions, but needed to extend the filling cook time to 30 minutes.
Everyone loved these bars!  I was told that they beat anything you'd find at a specialty bakery.  That's saying something, folks!
However, credit MUST go to Patty!  Her recipe started it all!

Fantastic!  The crust was nice, crisp, and buttery- exactly how I love it.  And the lemon filling was just right.  I took the advice of other reviewers and added the lemon zest.  

Also a tip to make sure you get maxiumum juiciness out of your lemons- pop them in the microwave for about 15 seconds.  They yield much more juice this way!  

Very lemony, easy, and satisfying!  Throw away the boxed stuff and make these!

The title of this dessert and the introduction pretty much sums it all up!...The best lemon bars I have ever had.
---UPDATE---I have been making these for a while now and although I believe they are perfect as written I have recently discovered using 1 Cup Icing Sugar mixed with 2 1/2 TBSP. of Real Lemon Juice (From concentrate/bottle)& 2 drops of yellow food colouring  to make a glaze and pour this glaze over the dessert as soon as they come out of the oven and allow to cool in pan. It's unbelievibly great for those tart lemon lovers with a sweet tooth. Also, keep these bars in the fridge they keep their form better then at room temp.

text:
With nearly 1,000 reviews, I don't know that I'm adding much, but these are my favorite dessert to make for myself, throwing parties, and to bring to events. I make three minor adjustments based on other reviews: add 1/4 tsp salt to crust; use 2/3 cup fresh-squeezed lemon juice (more precise than measuring by number of lemons); add 1 Tbsp flour to custard because of extra juice. The result: perfection. Everyone loves them, everyone asks for my recipe, and friends give me lemons from their trees because they want lemon bars in return. I really can't say enough good things about these.

text:
My mother always made these when I was a kid, now I make them all the time!  They have a buttery crust and gooey delicious lemon filling.  In the filling we use 2 cups of sugar and at least 1/3 cup lemon juice (and yes, you can substitute the lemon juice from a bottle).  I bake mine 20 min for the crust and an additional 25 with the filling (you want the filling slightly golden brown--a little too long in the oven is better than not long enough).  Dust with powdered sugar while they are still warm so it will stick.

text:
These are really good. At first I thought the crust was too thick but now that they've cooled overnight and set up, the crust really is perfect. Definitely add salt to the crust; it comes out nice and buttery-tasting. For the lemon filling, I used 1/3 cup plus 2 tbsp. lemon juice and the zest of 1/2 lemon (whisk it into the dry ingredients before adding liquids). I used about 1/3 cup of flour. The flavor is PERFECT, nice and tart. I lined my baking pans with foil for easy lift-out, and both the crust and the filling stuck to the foil really badly. I'd definitely suggest spraying your pans with cooking spray; if I hadn't used foil, I have no idea how I'd get these out of the pan. With these changes, I'll make these again and again.

text:
I gave this recipe 3 stars as written. The crust should never be more than half the overall height of the lemon bar and with this recipe it was. Also, I prefer a dominant, slightly tart lemon flavor in the custard. That being said, this is what I did to make this recipe a 5 star to me. For the crust I used 1/2 cup butter, 1 1/4 cup flour, 1/4 cup sugar, a pinch of salt and the zest of 2 lemons. The custard I used 4 eggs, 1 1/4 cups sugar, 5 tablespoons flour, and 2/3 cup fresh lemon juice (3 lemons). I baked it in a 9x9" with parchment on the bottom. Cool completely before cutting.

text:
First off, this recipe is VERY easy to make given that it is homemade.  I really recommend it for any new bakers out there.  I JUST finished this recipe and followed it almost exactly as called for.  The ONLY changes I made were to use 3 large lemons and a bit of lemon juice just to get to 2/3rds of a cup of juice.  I then added 1 tablespoon flour to the mix as a previous reviewer suggested.  I just tasted it and it is VERY lemony delicious.  (VERY lemony) So, for anyone that wants to make sure they get a lemon flavor, I would say squeeze at least enough lemons to get a 1/2 cup of juice.  THE TASTE OF THE CRUST IS AMAZING.  Do not listen to those that said it has no flavor.  It is rich, buttery, and melts in your mouth.  You do not want the crust to be too sweet, because the filling is VERY VERY sweet (trust me).  This crust balances that sweetness.  The only difficulty I had with the crust portion was the bake time, and no I do not know why (probably my oven).  I baked it for 30 minutes and it still slightly undercooked in my opinion, but still MORE than edible.  Next time, I will bake the crust for 40 minutes.  I just put it in the fridge and I can't WAIT to share it with everyone tomorrow.  It is TRULY fantastic.  This was so simple to make and very inexpensive ingredients.  TRY IT.

OK, I made these last night with a few changes based on some of the reviews I read. I kept the crust ingredients the same, but when it came to the filling I detoured a bit. If you want a sweet lemony bar that gives you a PUCKER EFFECT on your first bite, with a good filling to crust ratio, this is what I did...I kept the 4 eggs, increased the sugar to 2 cups, increased the flour to a third of a cup, and used the zest and juice of SIX lemons. These changes took these bars over the top! I had to bake a little longer, and when they were completely cooled I dusted with a little powered sugar. Enjoy!

text:
Since I know how to bake, I was able to make the steps that aren't really described here (such as how to crumble the butter into the flour until desired consistency).  That being said, even with the addition of the zest of one lemon, these were not the best I've had.  I believe there is a bit too much flour in the egg mixture, mine came out being rather eggy and too stiff.  The crust was slightly overcooked, doing 20 minutes and then a further 15 with egg/lemon mix.  I must say that if I had followed the recipe exactly (not adding the zest and even extra juice) that these would not have been edible, to me.  I would recommend the following changes:  adding the zest of one lemon, and the juice of an extra one, plus pre-baking the crust for only 12-15 minutes.  Also, adding salt to both the preparations, about 1/2 tsp.  Hope that helps.

text:
Yum! While not as good as the ones I can get at at my local bakery, these really aren't bad at all. Having said this, I did make a few tweaks to suit my tastes. As MommyFromSeattle did, I also upped the amount of lemon juice (1/2 c. / ~ 2-3 lg. lemons - I was able to squeeze 1/2 c. of juice out of 2 lemons) and 2 lemon's worth of zest. Before I added my eggs, I tested my filling to ensure that it was to my liking. The sweet / tart ratio was perfect for me, but you may prefer otherwise (if you like em' sweet, go with less juice, etc.). I think 2/3 c. juice would make these far too tart, but that's just my $.02. :) I baked my bars in an 8x8 in. stoneware baking dish to ensure they'd be nice and thick (I do not like thin bar cookies). It took 30 minutes for my crust to cook to a light golden brown color and 25 minutes for my filling to cook thru. NOTE: If you are going to dust your bars with powdered sugar (HIGHLY recommended!), be sure to do so when they are warm - right out of the oven is ideal. If you wait until your bars have cooled, the sugar will not "stick." One more observation.... If you refrigerate until completely cool, these will firm up nicely and be MUCH easier to cut into uniform squares. Using a plastic knife also seems to work well. Thanks for sharing your recipe, Patty! I will be sending my hubs with a plate of these to take to his office tomorrow. :-)

text:
These bars are a delight.  Great texture and lemon flavor.  I used 6 T. fresh lemon juice (4 small lemons) and about 1 tsp. of grated fresh lemon peel.  My butter was unsalted so I added 1 tsp. of salt to the crust dough.  The salt is necessary if you aren't using salted butter.  One more note and it is crucial:  You MUST grease your pan - at least on the sides.  I followed the recipe and did NOT treat the pan and the cookies adhered to the sides of the pan like concrete.   No problem though-after I maneuvered the bars out of the pan, I chiseled off the baked on sides and ate them myself.  YUM!

text:
I have baked for years but never tried a lemon bar.  Mainly because I never cared much for lemon until a few years ago.  I made this recipe with suggestions from the other reviewers.  I lined a 9 x13 aluminum pan with parchment paper.  Next I beat the room temp. eggs for 7 minutes then added only 1 1/2 cups sugar, added 1 loosely packed tablespoon of lemon zest, & not quite 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice.  My 3 lemons were not as juicy as I had hoped they would be.  I baked the crust for about 23 min. & added the filling to it without cooling & cooked it for 22 minutes.  It was well set & lightly browned on top.  After cooling on the counter for 45 min. I sprinkled confectioner's sugar on top & placed it in the fridge.  After dinner I removed the parchment paper without a problem of sticking, cut it into bars, & my husband & I ate several bars with coffee.  Having never eaten a lemon bar I have nothing to compare it with but next time I would add 2/3 cup of lemon juice & pack the tablespoon full of zest.  I might even only use 1 cup of sugar because we like tartness.  This was a little too sweet but the crust was perfect.  Is the consistency supposed to be a gummy consistency because these were.  They were very firm in texture & look like the pics included with the recipe.  Overall, they were good.  With the above changes, I will make this again.

I used the juice of five lemons and it came out delightfully tart, just how I like it.  This was fine because I also used an 8x11 pan and so the bottom was thick enough to offset the tartness.  The only problem with using so much juice is that when you put the powdered sugar on it tends to mostly melt in by the time you take it out to eat it.  I would put the sugar on when it comes out just to give it a little glaze, and powder it again right before serving for the visual effect.

text:
I am a lemon recipe connoisseur! These are the easiest, best tasting lemon bars I have ever made!
A couple of tips:
I always use a glass pan when baking lemon recipes, because the crust and edges are less likely to darken and crisp up too much.  If using a metal pan, dark or not, I lessen the temperature by at least 10 degrees and even more for a dark metal pan.  Sometimes bake times must be at lower temp and for longer time, and you can use your best judgment by looks during baking.
I agree whole-heartedly with MommyFromSeattle: Use at least 2/3 cup of lemon juice and add lemon zest if you have it!  This time I did not have fresh lemons on hand, so I used lemon juice from the bottle and added 2 teaspoons of organic lemon flavoring and used her advice to add the extra Tablespoon of flour for the filling.  This allows for that extra tart, super-sweet pop of flavor!
Instead of icing, I like to sift powdered sugar over the top, and one can do this immediately after baking to keep it from poofing up everywhere, and a little extra after bars are plated makes for gorgeous presentation!
Another thing I like to do with lemon bars is add crushed mint to my crust.  I added two teaspoons of crushed mint this time, and I think it was the perfect hint to complement the lemon flavor without tasting overwhelmingly of mint.
I did make one substitution:  I used half cup of butter half cup of coconut oil.
I think this recipe would also work for a graham crust, and plan to try it soon!
Mmm-MM!

text:
I'm kind of surprised how well this recipe is rated. I made the crust as is and there is WAY too much crust! I like crust as much as the next girl but the ratio is way off - almost 2:1 crust  to filling. If you're going to try this recipe, my suggestions are:
- halve the crust recipe
- add pinch of salt (1/8 tsp) to crust
- use smaller pan for a thicker bar
- use at least 2/3 cup lemon juice, add lemon zest if you like more tartness, add 1tbsp flour to account for more liquid
- don't forget to adjust baking time if you make changes to the crust or pan size.

Honestly, having to make so many changes to a recipe makes it a little disappointing.

The filling took  25 min.  Better too done than not done enough.  I sprinkled coconut on mine when there was about 10 min. left of cooking.  Excellent.  May just double the lemon fillilng next time.

text:
This is FABULOUS!  I made an amalgam of modifications based upon other user's hints, including adding lemon zest, warming lemons 15 seconds in microwave before squeezing, doubling filling to get a thick bar, baking longer.  I needed a LOT - 2 9 x 13 Pyrex baking dishes.  Here's exactly what I did:
Crust: 2 Cups soft butter, 1 Cup white sugar, 4 Cups all purpose flour, 2 tsps lemon zest. I creamed the butter with a hand mixer, added the sugar gradually, added the zest, added the flour 1 cup at a time. I divided the dough between the two Pyrex dishes. Do not bother trying to pat dough up sides of dish..it just melts and slides down the side so you might as well just pat it out evenly over the bottom and forget the sides.  Bake at 350 for 20 min. till slightly brown and remove from oven.
Filling: 6 Cups white sugar, 3/4 cup flour, 2 1/2 Cups lemon juice,16 eggs, 1 T. lemon zest.  Mixed sugar & flour with whisk, added lemon juice, added zest, added the eggs which had been beaten separately.  I beat all for a couple of minutes with a hand mixer, till smooth, no lumps.  This, I divided between the two pans of hot, prepared, baked dough, evenly.  I returned the dishes to the oven and baked them for 30 minutes more, removed from oven, and sprinkled heavily with powdered sugar while still hot, and let cool. They come out of Pyrex very easily. I used 1 1/2 c. fresh squeezed lemon juice and 1 c. bottled because I ran out of lemons.  It came out just wonderful!! Thanks to Patty et al..:)

These Lemon Bars really were the best! I'm genuinely shocked as easy they were to make. I brought them to our weekly meeting and people went for seconds! A little modification for you. I recommend "docking" (or pricking with a fork) the dough before putting it in the oven. Especially if you are using a glass pan (like I did). It's a lot harder to cut when you haven't docked the pastry part. It's also really hard to cut with a knife if it's been refrigerated. I will definitely be making these little treats all Spring/Summer long!

text:
This is one of my favorite recipies, and a big hit with the people I cook for on occasion. Though there are two edits I've found make it much better.

First off: double the lemon juice. Two lemons worth just doesn't seem to pack enough zing for those of us who love tart food.

And second: Once the crust is done, take it out, put it somewhere to cool for ten to fifteen minutes, then pour the filling in and put it back in the oven for the 20 minutes. I started doing this by accident and it seems to keep the crust from separating or getting too crisp. As well as stopping that strange effect where the filling burns on the edges of the glass dish.

'course, if you don't HAVE these problems... feel free to ignore this, heh.

I noticed that lemon is one of those ingredients that when added to a recipe, one person might think it is too sweet and the next person might think it was too tart, so I didn't place too much emphasis on others' suggestions when it came to whether is was too tart or too sweet - I only experimented and made it to my liking. text:
I made these in a Pampered Chef bar pan which I buttered. Then I mixed the 2 c. flour, 1 c. butter and 1/2 c. sugar in a food processor. Poured the crumbs into the pan and spread evenly before pressing down. I *doubled* the filling, using both lemon and lime juice and zest. Baked for 25 minutes. Perfection! Compliments all around. My daughter is licking her plate! UPDATE: I made this again, using the same crust technique. I baked the crust for 20 minutes. While that was baking I mixed up the filling, which I doubled, in the food processor. (No need to clean the left-over crust crumbs out.) First I put in 8 eggs and pulsed. Then I added the 3 c. of sugar with the processor running. Next I added the zest and juice of 2 lemons, plus an additional 9 T. of bottled lemon juice. (Taste and see if it's tart enough.) Then I added 1/2 c. plus 2-3 T of flour. I baked it for an additional 20 minutes. UPDATE: Next time I'll only add the 1/2 c. flour and bake for 15 minutes in an attempt to get a looser filling.

text:
I always try every recipe at least 2x; once the way its written and the second time, with any changes I felt were needed so I can compare.  This is a great recipe BUT..it DOES need some changes...sorry! The crust is just TOO thick. EVen after it cooled in the original. The crust was almost thicker than the lemon. Maybe some people like that, but we wanted to taste more of the lemon. The shortbred itself is outstanding-just halve the recipe for the crust (Which is what we did the 2nd time) or double the lemon ingredients.  I also used 3 whole lemons and zested all 3 the second time around. They werent very juicy so I did also supplement with concentarted lemon juice to make 3/4 cup. It was PERFECT. Much more tart than the original recipe. I also used 3 eggs and that made it a little thicker second time around.  All in all a great basic recipe that you can tweak as you see fit.

I made this in a slightly smaller pan than the 9x13. They came out nice and thick but a bit too much for me. I am now making a second batch in the pan size called for the recipe. text:
Very good!  I followed other's suggestions to up the lemon juice (to about 3/4 cup or 5 lemons, which will make a very tart bar but that's the way I like it) plus the increased flour to balance it out (1/3 cup).  Added the 1/4 tsp. of salt.  Added the zest of 2 lemons.  In the end I increased the ingredients by 50% and made it in my lasagna pan, and I thought the thickness of the bar was perfect this way.  I also baked the bottom part first for at least 25 minutes (kept my eye on it until the edges were browned), cooled it, then added the lemon custard and baked it for at least 25 minutes, eying it again to see when it looked ready (slightly browned on the top).  Next time I'll copy down the exact amount of time it took so I'll know for next time.

text:
These are fabulous.  I like my lemon bars tart, so I used 1/2 c fresh lemon juice. It wasn't too tart, or too sweet - a nice balance.  I also decided to use an 8x8 square pan and I made sure to coat it generously with PAM before baking.  And because I used a smaller pan, I didn't quite use all the crust, and cooked it a tish longer because the crust was thicker in the smaller pan.  The crust is pretty wet and gooey but don't worry, it comes out great. My crust was brown on the sides but a very light golden color in the middle and that worked out just great.  I let the crust cool completely before pouring in the filling and they came out just wonderfully. I took them out when the middle was not longer "jiggly". I didn't experience the strong "eggy" smell several people have remarked about.  They were just delicious - a definite keeper!

text:
These are the best lemon bars. I won't be using any other recipe ever again. I don't like recipes that you had to look through 200 reviews to find the changes to make the recipe work. This one works as written and is delicious. 

I made these last night as a surprise for my husband. He likes sweets in moderation, but went crazy for these lemon bars and ate 3 in one sitting. He said they looked and tasted like a bakery had made them.

I have tried recipes and had the crust crumbles apart when serving, or had the curd taste like sweet goo not lemons, or worse, had the curd harden like scrambled eggs. The crust was like shortbread, firm and crunchy like a cookie (not a cracker), very tender and short. The topping was the perfect lemon curd consistency, nice and gooey, but not runny. They were nice combination of tart and sweet, just like lemonade.  

I changed nothing about the recipe, except that I used butter flavored Crisco instead of butter because that is a substitution I always make and I greased the pan so they wouldn't stick.

As for lemons, I picked 3 good sized lemons from the tree, zested and juiced them. I had about 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice. I pulled the bars out when the center no longer jiggled and that was perfect. 

These are the best lemon bars I have ever made or eaten.

text:
WOW!  Just made these and they are SO good.  I did make a couple of adjustments based on other reviews.  Here's what I did:  I kept them in a 9 x 13 pan but greased it.  I don't know if it was necessary but my bars didn't stick.  I followed the crust directions but added a LITTLE bit of salt even though I used salted butter.  I baked the crust just until it started to brown and then let cool completely.  I did have to bake for a bit more than the 20 minutes in the recipe.    

For the filling I used 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice.  Two lemons would not have been very much but I used small lemons.  I increased the flour to 1/3 cup to compensate for the extra lemon juice. I went to removed the bars after baking 20 minutes and the center seemed like it was not set at all so I baked for another 5.  

These set up nicely and the crust was perfect.  They were still yummy the next day.  I agree that they smell a bit eggy when they come out of the oven but don't taste that way at all, especially when cool.  I can't wait to make them again!

text:
These were better than store bought lemon bars and very easy. I took other reviewers' advice, and used 2/3 cup lemon juice (didn't have real lemons so used Real Lemon juice) 1/3 c. flour (dumped that in first, then slowly stirred in liquids), and also added 1/4 tsp of salt to the crust. I ran out of normal white sugar, so I also added 1/2 c of brown sugar. It didn't discolor them at all and they were extremely tasty! It did take about 25 minutes to bake. I found the lemon flavor is slightly stronger the second day. Also, I found the powdered suger did dissolve into the bars a bit but they were still good. With the variations, the bars appealed to a wide range of tastes (not to tart or too sweet). I took them to our church gathering and got many complements. Only a couple small pieces were left, which my husband and I enjoyed today!

I love tangy lemony squares without too much crust. So In order to perfect these I made the following changes: use a 9x13 pan, and  keep crust same except add 1/4 teaspoon of salt to it. Prepare 1.5x  the filling ingredients except lemon- maybe a tad more flour for firmness due to the extra liquid added, I use  1 cup of  lemon juice in this amount of filling. I also added zest of 1 lemon (optional). I found this to be the best ratio of sweet to tangy, crust to filling, and they are firm on the outside but gooey on the inside. Definitely cut after refrigerating overnight and then use a clean knife dipped in hot  water for clean edges.

text:
I liked this recipe, but made a few tweeks.   As a previous reviewer suggested, adding the 1/4 teaspoon salt to the dough gives it flavor.  Also, you cannot pat this dough into a 9x13 pan without having an uneven crust.  I would suggest three things:  first, chill the dough for 20 minutes prior to baking.  Second, line the pan with parchment.  Third, take the dough out of the refrigerator and let rest for 10 minutes prioor to rolling between two sheets of parchment.  This will enable you to achieve an even rectangle cemmensurate wit the pan size--it also makes it easier to fit the dough into the pan!  Bake dough 20 minutes and let cool to room temperature.   I like a lot of lemon, so I found using only 3 lemons did not equal 2/3 cup (another reviewer also suggested using 2/3 cup).  I used smaller lemons, which equates to 5 or 6 lemons.

text:
I haven't had too too many lemon bars in my life, but I agree--these are the best I've had!

We had an abnormally hot day in April that made me really crave summery things--so when an office birthday presented itself as an opportunity for me to break out the bakeware, I decided on making lemon bars.

These lemon bars were pretty amazing.  I made a few changes to the recipe, based on the reviews:

- FILLING: I used the juice of 3 lemons (about 3/4 cups), added zest from two of those lemons, and added a little more flour to the filling.  Even though I used more lemon juice and the same amount of sugar, I found that the filling was still a little too sweet for my taste.

- CRUST: I added a pinch of salt to the crust--though the crust was still semi tasteless for me.  I think I may add some extra lemon zest to the shortbread (from the last lemon), and maybe a little pinch of vanilla or ginger or something to give a little spice and warmth.  I also think I'd transfer the extra sugar from the filling into the crust.

This recipe makes about a 1:1 ratio of crust to filling; so, if you like that, then follow this recipe!  If you like more filling, then scale up the filling!  I baked in an 8x8 dish, which made some pretty fat lemon bars -_-  still, they were tasty!

Dust with powdered sugar on top--mMmmMm!!! :)

Simple and yummy. After reading other reviewer suggestions, I did the following: I used 2/3 cup fresh lemon juice (and an extra 1 tbs of flour into the filling mix to counter the extra liquid) and added the zest into the crust. I added a pinch of salt into the crust mix as well.

text:
Awesome recipe!  I made a couple of tweaks to it though.  First, I used an 8x11 glass pan instead of my 13x9.  I like my lemon bars a little thicker, but I think if you were to double the recipe you would get nice thick bars in a 13x9 pan.  Since I used a smaller pan, I had to add about 5-10min on to each baking section.  Second, for the lemon custard, I like my lemon bars really lemony.  I only had small lemons so I only managed to get 1/2cup of lemon juice.  So I also zested two of the lemons, and added about 2tspns of lemon extract.  They came out nice and tart, but also a little sweet, and the shortbread crust came out awesome.  I would also suggest letting it cool, and then popping in the fridge to help the custard solidify before serving.  I can't stop eating them!  Delicious!

text:
Truly the best lemon bars I've ever had. I use between 1/2 cup to 3/4 cup lemon juice as recommended by other reviewers. (This is a way more accurate way to describe how much lemon you'll need- perhaps the only flaw in the recipe.) I use a food processor for the crust. Mine usually comes out fine, but if yours doesn't hold together (it could be the humidity or how you measured the flour), you can add one egg or just a yolk for easier handling characteristics.

Anyway: the BEST lemon bars ever.

Made these with limes and used 1/2 cup (3 limes) juice, plus the zest from the limes.  Also used 1 tbs. extra juice for a more tart bar, otherwise followed the recipe as stated, and they turned out perfect. I wouldn't have wanted the crust any thicker, and would have not wanted any more filling as it was so tart. I did spray the pan with cooking spray before pressing in the crust.  also let the crust cool before adding the filling to bake, and chilled bars for easier cutting. No problem getting them out of the pan if you have the right tools. This one is a keeper!

text:
I don't normally take the time to write reviews, but I was craving something sweet  yesterday and decided to try this recipe. The lemon bars were AMAZING!!! Thank you, Patty, for sharing your recipe! I read a ton of the reviews, used several of their tweaks, and the bars were perfect. I followed the recipe, but added 1/4 tsp. salt to the crust, used 3 LARGE lemons to get 2/3 cup fresh lemon juice, added 2 tsp. lemon zest, added an extra 2 tsps. of flour to the filling, and dusted the lemon bars with powdered sugar when they came out of the oven. I also USED A SMALLER PAN (11x8) so the lemon bars were thick. I ended up with a 1:1 ratio of crust to filling, which was perfect.  I also baked the crust for a full 20 minutes. The lemon bars were very tart and the crust tasted just like a shortbread cookie. They do take a while to cool down and firm up...Make sure you bake the lemon bars until the filling is firm and not jiggly.
*tip: If you put the lemons in the microwave for 15 seconds, they are easier to juice!

I used this recipe as a base for gluten free lemon bars and they came out perfect!  Changes to make this gluten free: use all purpose gluten free flour in crust and add 1 tsp salt. Perfect flavor and texture for the cookie crust. For the filling I used 1 tbsp cornstarch instead of flour to thicken. Following other comments we used 2/3 cup lemon juice and the zest of 2 lemons and added a pinch of salt as well. The flavor on these is beyond perfect. The cooking time did need to be increased as we used a smaller pan but overall a great recipe.

text:
These are amazing ! I made two batches. The first was exactly how the recipe was written ( used 1/2 cup lemon juice) and these were fantastic. Week later we were invited to a picnic and I decided to make these again, but noticed just how much sugar is in this recipe(2 full cups!) So I made these again with the following changes: Reduced the sugar in the crust from 1/2 cup to 1/4 cup and reduced the sugar in the lemon mixture from 1-1/2 cups to just 1 cup. So 3/4 of a cup less sugar and these still turned out great ! They disappeared quickly at the picnic amidst lots of compliments !

text:
Recipe is nearly perfect with two small exceptions - add the juice of 3 lemons rather than just the 2 called for, and you will get a much more distinctive lemon flavour and juicier / more lemon curd-like texture on the top layer.  I also find than an extra 5-10 minutes on baking the crust gives it a nicer crunchier texture. 

Serving suggestion: cut up a punnet of strawberries and cover w/ 1 tsp of sugar.  Squeeze the juice of one lime over the strawberries and sugar, and leave to soak for at least an hour.  Add a little water if there's not enough juice when you're ready to serve, then spoon the strawberries and juice over the lemon bars when you plate them.

text:
Excellent - best lemon bar recipe I have used.  Two suggestions:
1) Grate the rind of both lemons and use the rind in the bottom crust
2) Make sure your lemons are at room temperature and roll them hard on your counter to soften them up before juicing them.  You will get the most juice if you do this.  

If you do both of the above it will be plenty lemony and you won't need any extra lemon juice.

text:
Lemon is a spring/summer flavor staple so of course I had to give these a shot! I always read reviews before baking and make adjustments if need be. Now, little fact, I always half recipes the first time I am trying a new recipe. I don't want to waste a whole bunch of ingredients on a failure you know? So I did that. I also took the advice from my fellow bakes and up'd the lemon. Yes I only used one, but a riper one with lots of juice. I also used the zest of that lemon. This resulted in a tangier bar with a nice but subtle punch of flavor. I also would have liked to know beforehand to let my crust cool before pouring my lemon filling. As a novice baker, this kind of stuff slips my mind. The bars tasted fine, but there was air pockets. Not many. I tried again and let the crust cool and the surface of my bars were so smooth. So remember to let that cool. All in all, great recipe. I have already made this thrice!

text:
These lemon bars are amazing! Our family has loved lemon squares for as long as i can remember and even before i was born and after we lost our original recipe, things were never the same. All the other recipes i used were either WAY TOO SWEET or had way too much crust and an almost invisible layer of filling. I used 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice and added two teaspoons of lemon rind, it wasn't even very tart! Just how i like it. I cooked the crust until it was golden brown on the edges and then cooked it again with the filling. WOW it turned out soo good and the filling was soo gooey and delicious. Remember not to overcook  the filling! It should be gooey. Anyways, I've finally found the perfect recipe and will keep it in my recipe box for future use. Thanks so much for sharing THE BEST LEMON BARS EVER.

country:
None
text:
The basic recipe here is sound, but definitely heavy on crust and very light on lemon; with some changes, it's definitely a 5-star recipe. The crust needs 1/2 teaspoon of salt (or use salted butter); lemon zest is nice, too. The original custard is very scant and not at all lemony enough. I doubled the quantity of filling, increased the lemon-to-sugar ratio because I like my lemon desserts tart and bright (I increased the lemon juice to 1 and 1/4 cups and decreased the sugar to 2 and 3/4 cups), and added 2 tablespoons of flour to help it set, due to the extra juice. I cooked my bars in two 8x8 pans instead of one 9x13, but the total surface area of the pans are very close; my bars were just a smidge thinner than they would have been in a 9x13. I baked the crusts for 20-25 minutes and the filled pans for 30 more, and a 9x13 would be almost identical. The original recipe was blah, but with these changes the results were definitely among the best lemon bars I've tried.

text:
This was my first try at Lemon Bars and I thought they came out pretty good.  I made them for a bridal shower and one woman claimed they were the best she's ever had (and she claimed to be a bit of a connoisseur).  I followed the advice of another reviewer and used an 8 x 11" pan to yield thicker bars.  I used meyer lemons and increased the lemon juice to just shy of 2/3 cup (juice of 3 good sized lemons).  I also added an extra tablespoon of flour to compensate for the extra liquid.  I think next time I will also added the zest of 2 of the lemons.  I also added 1/4 teaspoon salt to the crust for more flavor.  I read that it's better to overcook then undercook the crust....but next time I will keep a better eye on it as I think I did go a bit too far with the crust this time around.  Overall a very good recipe!

text:
This is now my go to recipe for lemon bars.  I was tempted to give 4 stars because of the need to alter the recipe.  Based upon reviews and my love of tart lemon I followed combined reviews of: Mommyfrom seattle and sugarboo in making them.  I used 3/4 cup lemon juice, zest of 2 lemons to custard, added salt 1/4 tsp salt and 2 Tbs flour to custard. - I doubled the recipe,  (amounts above are for single recipe.) Because of this I added 5 mins. to crust bake time and app. 7 mins to custard time.  They turned out perfectly. However, next time I plan to double only the custard and decide which crust I prefer. The crust is a light, buttery shortbread flavor. - Its an easy recipe, I used an ungreased, 9x13, glass baking dish and they popped right out. Allow the crust to cool for awhile prior to adding the custard, otherwise the eggs start to cook on the hot crust. - Trickiest part for me was making the desired changes to original recipe based upon the reviews.

text:
I have a recipe for lemon bars that people really love, but I tried this one for a change and shared them with my friends. No one liked them as much. The recipe I normally use has a thick, rich lemon CURD that is cooked on the stove before before being added to the parbaked crust and finished off in the oven, I think that is what makes the difference. While making the curd I add in the zest of the lemons in order to get the great oils from the peels and then strain them out before adding the cooked curd to the crust. But this recipe is much easier I must admit.

text:
Never tried something like this before, but they turned out pretty great!

I used a (glass) 8x11 pan as suggested by another member, and added about halfway between 1/2 and 2/3 cups of lemon juice for the custard. Even so, the bars seemed like they could've been a bit more lemony. I also noticed that the crust seemed to outweigh the custard a bit (in volume as well as flavor).

The crust took quite a bit longer than expected (even after adding 5-10 minutes for the different pan size) and was still pretty chewy in the center by the time they were finished. On the other hand, the custard was definitely done within 25-30 minutes.

Even though they weren't my favorite dessert ever, everyone that tried them loved them, and the whole pan was gone within an hour of serving them. I definitely recommend this recipe and will be making them again soon!

I love this recipe because it has simple ingredients and lends itself to creativity. I've made it a few times before as written, and this time I made a few alterations that I was pretty happy with. I couldn't find a 9x13 pan so I used my 8" glass pie pan and spread the shortbread along the bottom and the sides. (I had extra that I set aside for something else). This worked out well, but it poofed up a lot and I had to flatten it (forgot to pierce with a fork). Still ended up with a pretty nice crust though.
For the filling I did about half lemon and half lime juice, and substituted one cup of the sugar for one cup of date paste (dates processed in blender with a little water). The resulting "pie" was very lemony/limey, and the dates added a nice, rich flavor without taking away any of the sweetness. In fact, I think next time I will skip the sugar altogether and just use the cup of date syrup. Yum.

These are absolutely delicious! I made them about a month ago and again today. They work quite well GF :) I used a flour mix with 6 parts rice flour, 2 parts potato starch, and 1 part tapioca flour. I doubled the filling both times (they had to cook about 15 min longer) and used more lemon :) I also added about 1 tsp of salt to the crust. The first time I was short on lemons so I added some extra orange juice concentrate and the turned out wonderfully! This time I did 4 lemons (they only turned out 2/3 cups of juice) and added more lemon juice to equal 1 1/3 cups. I added almost 2/3 cups of flour to compensate for the extra liquid :) These are so easy and delicious, I will always use this recipe!

I'm eating one of these now and I feel like I've died and gone to lemony heaven. I made the following changes:  I cut softened margarine into the flour and sugar mixture and lightly kneaded the dough before pressing it into the pan, which I'd greased and lightly floured.  I used 6 eggs and about 3/4 cup lemon juice (3 lemons)  I added the zest from the 3 lemons.  I doubled the flour.  The resulting lemon bars have a generous amount of tangy, not too sweet, filling. Plus the bars are easy to get out of the pan.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a good starting point, but after reading many reviews it requires too much tweeking to be rated 5 stars.  Picking and choosing from the many tips, here's what I did and the bars came out quite tasty.  Crust - added 1/4 tsp of salt and 1 tsp of zested lemon peel.  Let butter soften (but still cool) and cut it into the dry ingredients.  Filling - Wanted a thicker bar so I scaled the recipe to 55 and used those ingredient amounts (6 eggs, etc).  Used my hand mixer ( I'm not a good whisker) to beat the eggs until frothy.  Added dry ingredients and beat again.  With the sky high price of lemons, I used 1/3 cup freshly squeezed lemon juice and 1/3 cup bottled lemon juice, then added 3 Tbsp of flour and continued to beat.  Stirred into mixture 3 tsp of lemon zest.  Poured onto slightly cooled crust and baked at 350 for 25 to 30 minutes - edges just starting to turn golden brown.  Maybe it was using the hand mixer, these came out with a real nice thin sort of light sugary white looking crusty topping while the inside was just the right consistency.

These were really good. With a few modifications they would be even better.  Following the other reviewers, I did 2/3 c lemon juice (3 med size lemons), added 1 tbsp of flour to compensate for the extra liquid.  Added the zest of 1/2 lemon to the base and added the zest of 1 1/2 lemons to the topping.  I baked in a 8x11 pan (because I was worried they would be too delicate to transport to a pot luck).  My husband thought the filling could take more lemon, so next time I will add the zest of all the lemons.  The changes are minor and he has asked several times when a new batch will be made. I will definitely make these several times over the summer.

text:
The first time I made these I used 2/3 cup of lemon juice. From experience juicing lemons one lemon yields approximately 1/3 cup. I also used 1 tespoon pure lemon extract because of what other reviewers had said about the taste not being tart enough. I also used all 4 eggs.  For my taste they wern't tart enough and even though the crust is really good, it does overwelm the topping.  The second time I made them with lime juice, also using the lemon extract, but cutting back to 3 eggs. It was better and the topping set up just as good with only 3 eggs. With one less egg I perceived the tartness better. However, if I was to make these again I will make the topping using 1 and 1/2 times the recipe so the crust doesn't overwelm the topping.

text:
I made two trays of this recipe: one with lemon juice and butter, the other with lime juice and margarine. For those who find the original recipe to have an overpowering butter flavor, I suggest using margarine instead. The bars still taste delicious minus the butter overload. I also used the juice of three lemons/limes as other reviewers had suggested. In the future, I will only use two limes in the lime version as three limes made the bars a little more tart than I would have liked. Three lemons in the lemon version was just the right amount. All in all, I found this to be a simple and delicious recipe. I will definitely make these again.

text:
I decided to use this lemon bar recipe over the "bake sale lemon bars" recipe for 2 reasons; they both had the same ingredients in different amounts, and the reviews on the bake sale lemon bars were too 50/50. I just put my lemon bars in the oven for the last 20 minute bake so I'll have to update this review as soon as I taste them! But so far, so good... I did add 1 1/2 tbsp of lemon zest (being careful not to over zest), and it took 2 medium, 1 large, and 1 small lemon, to be exact, for me to reach the 2/3 cup of lemon juice (as suggested by other reviews). I decided to add the extra tbsp of flour also suggested by most of the reviews. I had a bit of difficulty spreading out the crust to line the bottom of my 9x13 metal pan, but if you're patient with it, and spread it as evenly as possible, the dough is just right to fit a 9x13. I baked the crust for 16 minutes, and it came out perfect! Not browned on top, but perfectly light-golden brown on the corners and edges. The recipe did not state to let the crust cool, so I didn't start mixing the filling together until the crust was completely out of the oven (allowing it to cool for at least 5-10 minutes while I mixed the filling).***UPDATE*** Baked, cooled, sugared, & eaten. The crust/filling ratio was off (too much crust) but it came out pretty good. Not too sweet, not too tart. The top of the bars had this chewy baked over crust (the browned part of the filling) which I couldn't ignore :( so that's why 4 stars.

text:
I must suggest using Meyer lemons. They are very sweet lemons that some people eat like oranges. They are a richer color than other lemons. And I have found the zest is better in cooking and baking. These lemons will ensure that the bars will not be too tart, but you can still use 5 lemons and get a great lemony taste. I found mine at Whole Foods. They were about $3 per pound, but I got 4 lemons in just under a pound. Lemons in the other grogery stores are so darned expensive at .79 each, this was no more expensive as a result. I believe Meyer lemons are native to Australia, however, they are grown in California. I can find them year round, but they go fast, so the store is often out of them.

text:
A lovely recipe, perfectly refreshing and simple. I am pretty sure I could eat one of these lemon bars every day. I followed the recipe more or less as written, but incorporated several of Mommyfromseattle's suggestions. I used 2/3 cups lemon juice (1/2 fresh and 1/2 bottled was what I had) and added 1 extra tablespoon flour. I also added the zest of 2 lemons. I made it in the size dish called for and it was the perfect amount of crust for me. I used margarine instead of butter for the crust and added 1/4 teaspoon salt. The perfect lemon bar, THANK YOU!  *****EDITED 4/3/09 TO ADD: I still adore this recipe. Just thought I would share one of my failed attempts: the crust shouldn't be made in advance! I had my crust already in the oven when I realized I didn't have enough eggs for the filling. I put my cooled crust in the fridge until I could get more eggs. The next day I completed the recipe as usual, but sadly much of the filling seeped down between the crust and the pan. It made a real mess, didn't set up properly or look right, and really affected the taste. Absolutely my own fault, not that of the recipe, but I thought I would mention it in case anyone thought they should try it this way!

text:
These lemon bars are AMAZING! I make a 1.5x batch for a 13"x9" glass pan and think they are a good thickness. I've made them twice now and have used about 2/3 c. of lemon juice one time and close to 1 c. the other time, both were good, but the batch with a full cup definitely had a good tartness to them. Both batches took longer to bake because of the larger size, but I just took the crust out when it was just starting to brown and the whole thing out when the filling no longer jiggles when the pan is gently shaken (I think that's actually what the recommended test for doneness is for the last boxed lemon bars I made XD). Compared to boxed lemon bars, the one thing that surprised me was how much more like a dough (and a *sticky* dough) the crust was, but it turns out really well. I would definitely recommend greasing the pan, although it does cause the very edges to brown or burn, but otherwise they're stuck to the pan anyway! Someone suggested refrigerating the crust to keep the filling from sinking in. I didn't do this the first time and teh bars were great, but I ended up having to the second time (had to leave the house for a couple of hours) and the filling kept falling off the crust when anyone tried to eat one! Not bad, just slightly messier I guess :)

I followed the suggestions and added more lemon to my filling. Way too much for me but still great lemon bars.I will cut the lemon down to half of what I used. That is just me though. Oh yum!  These are wonderful!  Absolutely lemony and delicious!  Will definitely make over and over again - at least while I'm craving lemon!

text:
These lemon bars are easy and amazing and take less than half an hour to prep. A few tips:

- The juice of two lemons is, in my opinion, too little and too vague. Depending on how lemony you want them, I use an overflowing 1/2 cup of lemon juice from a bottle. 
- Feel free to mix the crust mixture with your hands. It turns out crumbly and perfect. 
- For me, the crust takes longer than 20 minutes to bake. I recommend putting it in for 20 and testing the crust with the back of a spoon to see how hard/soft it is. If a noticeable amount of soft crust comes back, leave it in for another 5 minutes and check again. 
- The crust usually doesnt turn out perfectly golden, but a tan color still tastes delicious. 
- To make the bars look REALLY lemony, add a drop or two of yellow food coloring to the lemon mixture before adding it to the pan. 
- Of course, sprinkle powdered sugar over the top once cooled if desired. 

Enjoy these simple, delicious desserts!

text:
I followed the basic recipe for the short bread and added 1/4 tsp salt. I used a 9 x 13 pan (metal).  For the second layer, I used 2/3 c fresh squeezed lemons from my yard and 2 big tbs of zest. I zap the lemons for 30-40 sec in the microwave to help them let loose with the juice.  I also increased the sugar to 2 cups and the flour by 1- 1.5 Tbs for the increased liquid. I also cooked them about 5-10 min longer. Sprinkled with powdered sugar, and let them cool for an hour on the counter. Then I covered them and put the tray in the fridge for another hour and they were ready to cut. DELICIOUS! Buttery, tart, just the right amount of sweet.

text:
This is a fairly simple recipe that makes good lemon bars. Wish there was a specific measurement for the lemon juice as all lemons give a variable amount of juice. (A medium lemon gives approx. 2-3T of juice, a large one gives about 4T - according to thekitchn.com). I had a lot of Myers Lemons which can give 1/2-1c of juice, so I had to experiment and found that about 3T worked well. I used this higher amount as this type of lemon is milder. 
I made this recipe twice. Once as written and a second time substituting granulated Splenda for the sugar - equal amounts. We actually like the sugar-free version the best!

text:
These turned out great for me. I did take other reviewers advice and modified the recipe slightly. The base I left alone except for the addition of salt and about a tbls of Cardamom.
This is the recipe I used for the lemon layer:
6 eggs
2.5 cups sugar
1/2 cup + 2tbls of flour
1 cup Lemon Juice
1.5 tbls of lemon rind
I baked the base for 15 min. Let it cool for another 15, poured the lemon layer in and baked another 30 minutes. They set up perfectly. This is now my go to recipe for Lemon Squares.

text:
I have made lemon bars several times and have enjoyed them, not so with this one.  "Squeeze two lemons" doesn't give the reader knowledge of how much lemon to really put in the mix, if you really want a stronger flavor I would put in 7 tablespoons of lemon juice. 
The top part of this lemon bar recipe baked up kind of rubbery to me, when slicing into it the top layer comes up from the lower layer, the two should be baked together with softness, gooeyness.  
  There is not a mention of baking powder here, which gives it a little bit of rise.  
   Powdered sugar is great, in crust as well as wet mixture....then sprinkling it on top when it comes out of the oven.

text:
I dont think Ive ever reviewed a dish on here, but this one is not a good recipe for lemon squares at all! So here I am. There are much better lemon square recipes available. Ratio of crust to lemon curd is way too high. Too much egg for not enough lemon juice. The lemon curd in this recipe is unusual for a lemon square; its not thick enough at all. I usually use a double boiler to make my curd and should have just dont that for this. I will never make this recipe again and am super disappointed in it since it has such high reviews. I like the crust and it was easy, but its too much compared to the lemon part. Would use the crust again with my grandmothers lemon curd recipe to make this a decent lemon square recipe. It taste fine, but definitely didnt wow me. Definitely do not recommend if youre looking for a traditional lemon square recipe.

country:
None
text:
I've been using this recipe for years. I like it buttery, very citrusy and not as sweet. 
The shortbread recipe is unchanged, I use salted butter so I don't add extra salt to it. 
Instead of adding more lemon juice (and messing with the crust to filling ratio) I simply add less sugar in the filling (1 cup instead of 1.5 cups). 
I juice 3 lemons (or limes) and it usually falls between 1/2 -2/3 cup. 
I've done it with zest and without, but to me the less sugar in the filling is what really brings out the flavor.
Lemon or Lime is very tasty (I add green coloring to the lime ones)

text:
We made it in an 8x8x2 pan since I did not have the right size pan. We used a hair less than 1/2 a cup of lemon juice which is what 2 lemons gave and put zest in the lemon juice like Mommyfromseattle suggested. (we just used a knife and carefully sliced the yellow skin off and diced it, but avoid slicing too much b/c the white part underneath the yellow skin is bitter) She suggested 2/3 cup of lemon juice is better and I would agree to use that because the lemon custard was delicious and enough but it could use a bit more to be 100% satisfying. The 8x8 pan was too small for the amount of crust, so my crust is super thick. The lemon tart is delicious, but if the lemon bars were made in a bigger pan where the crust could be a normal thickness I could only imagine the lemon custard part being very thin with just 1/2 a cup of lemon juice. The recipe says nonstick spray is not suggested. I used another gluten free recipe for lemon bars which called for putting parchment paper around the pan and spraying the parchment paper with nonstick spray, and it may prevent the lemon tart from getting burnt at the edges. However my recipe didn't really follow the instructions so I am not sure if that's normal since my lemon bars did get burnt a bit at the edge.

I used the juice of 3 lemons, which ended up being about 2/3 cups of juice. I most certainly would not use any less! Also, I would suggest spraying the sides before pouring the lemon curd. 

You should also let the crust cool before pouring the lemon curd. 

Bring the eggs up to room temp. 

Use salted butter for the crust. 

Bake the bara until the lemon curd is just set. In other words It should jiggle like jello but not be stiff or liquidy. 

I personally don't like this crust, it needs something else.  I love the lemon curd recipe.

text:
Fantastic. The recipe is fine as is, but I did take advice and added a little extra lemon and some zest, just to kick it up a notch. I also cut back the sugar to have it less sweet (personal preference). The sugar called for is probably fine for most if you like sweets. I made this for Easter. The baking time for the crust worked fine for me. I did add a bit to the filling part - another 4 minutes or so. It sets when you chill it in the fridge. Also suggest letting the crust cool before adding the filling, so it doesn't all melt in.   Because I made this for Easter, just after I had dyed some eggs in blueberries, I topped the bars with the blueberry compote so it didn't go to waste. I also used a springform pan instead of a square baking dish - just for appearance. But it worked fantastically!

text:
My instincts told me to let the crust cool before pouring the lemon filling on top, but I wanted to just try the recipe as stated.  Pouring the lemon filling on top of the warm crust caused all the lemon filling to get baked into the crust itself and not have distinct layers.  Also 20 minutes of bake time was too much and edges and top were too brown. The end result looks more like a lemon crumb cake than traditional lemon bars.

I've made lemon bars with this recipe three times now with the first time being the only untweaked. My immediate CRITIQUES of the original recipe are:

1) Filling is not lemony enough. Needs the juice of about 4-5 lemons.

2) The filling was too sweet. I cut the sugar in half. 

The base shortbread crust recipe is great and I kept it as is. 

Tweaks I made were:

1) Filling: Added more lemon juice (about 3-4 lemons)

2) Filling: Increased baking time to about 22-24 mins

3) Filling: Cut sugar in half

4) Filling: Added lemon zest to top of baked crust and again on top of unbaked filling before putting it into the oven.

This is an amazing recipe.  I hemmed and hawed at reviewing this because I do change things, but it's because each lemon is different and I like it tart.  Because I like it really tart, I always add the lemon zest and taste it.  If it's not tart enough I will add some True Lemon powder from packets (not always).  But I would do that for any lemon bar including a box because I do like it it super tart as does my family.  

What I really love about this recipe is that it make a wonderful crust and has what I consider the perfect ratio of crust to lemon.  I will never buy a box again!

so two things i would add/change to the list of steps, which i did and i loved based on this list.

1. zest the lemons prior to extracting the juice and include that with the lemon juice and eggs.
2. expand the final cook time to include a range; maybe 15-20 minutes instead of a hard 20 minutes.

I loved the way this crust puffed up. I also took a taste like any good chef would do and it was like a perfect shortbread cookie taste. At first I didn't think when I pressed it down that it would be enough. But it doubled after baking. It needed almost 30 minutes for the bubbling in the middle to cook out and start getting lightly golden, but anyone that loves to cook knows everyone's ovens are a bit different. region:

country:
None
text:
Great recipie. I have made it quite a few times. I changed things just a bit. I like my lemon bars really tart, as does my husband. So my changes are.... I double the filling for the ingredients as in the recipie but I also, zest (roughly) and juice 2 lbs lemons (I juice over a sieve to remove pulp and seeds). I also blend together the sugar and flour till combined. Blend the zest in and then add al 8 eggs and blend until a pale fluffy yellow, after that I add the lemon juice and mix very well. The zest will get stuck in the mixer paddles, just bang that off into the batter.  I add a sprinkle of baking soda to the crust and leave the 1/2 cup sugar heaping for the crust. Dust with powdered sugar at the end and the pan will be gone same day!!

I noticed in the video that they stuck the measuring cup in the flour and scooped it up but if you want to get an accurate measurement, the correct way to measure flour is to spoon it into the measuring cup and then scraping it level. Measuring flour as they did in the video tends to pack the flour into the measuring cup resulting in a much denser  outcome.  I never thought much about it until I realized there was a noticeable difference in the end. All and all this was a good recipe

text:
These came out perfect. I added a heaping 1/4 teaspoon of salt to the crust and baked at 350degrees for 30 min. For the top i used 2/3 cup lemon juice and the zest of 2 large lemons. To make the perfect zest please note: use a veggie wash and scrub brush or baking soda works great too. The chemicals on your lemons will taint your recipes. Also dont grate any white peel just the yellow. This will give you so much more flavor!!! I also added an extra 1/4th cup of white sugar to compensate for the lemon juice (this is optional, i have a sweet tooth and like my desserts sweet). I also added an extra tablespoon of flour and a bit of vanilla (about a teaspoon). I poured immediately on hot crust and cooked for 25 minutes. When done i lined the outside edges with a wet knife and stuck in fridge and dusted with powdered sugar after they cooled a little bit. I noticed these taste wayyyy better on day 2 so i would make them the night before you plan on serving. :))

text:
There are so many reviews here, everything I say is probably already here.  But here goes - (1) I agree with the top rated helpful review - put the lemon zest in the custard.  I found a grater with almost small square, very fine holes - it is the kind you hold with a handle like a pancake turner. The brand is Microplane spice grater (cinnamon, ginger etc.)  I got lucky and bought it at a garage sale, new.  Before using, I wouldn't have paid the asking price of $14.95 but after having used it, I would now.  It is so easy to control and clean. The teeth are super sharp and it is effortless.  Clean with a brush.   You don't get hardly any pithy stuff when zesting oranges and lemons.  (2) I used 1/2 fresh lemon juice and Italia or Sicilia - they taste like fresh.  I can't believe one reviewer wrote that she used Realemon. That is awful. Especially after using the two brands I mentioned.  I did use 2/3 cup juice and added the extra Tbsp flour.    (3) I used 1/2 butter, 1/2 Imperial margarine. (4) the biggest change, I guess, was 1/2 whole wheat flour and 1/2 white all purpose and 1/4 tsp salt in the crust.  I put some salt in the custard too.  (5) strangely, they stuck to the pan a bit so I will spray lightly with cooking spray next time or use parchment paper. They were super lemony and super good.  Everyone at the school recital fund raiser dinner liked them.   

** PS i made a double batch the first go round and used a spring form for one.  Although I know spring form pans are

text:
As others said, it wasn't as tart as desired. I used 2 and a half lemons (came out to half a cup) and even taste-tested the filling before I poured it over the crust. I now realize that the crust took away some of the tartness of the filling, so if you decide to taste test, make the filling a bit more sour than you want. The bar itself tasted fine (I'll still eat it all), but was more like a cookie with a hint of lemon. Several other reviews have great notes on how to make the bars more tart, so take a look at them before you begin. If you don't like sour treats, however, follow the recipe as-is.

text:
Incredible cookie bars, sweet and tart, easy to make and fabulous!!  I live in Guatemala, and rarely find lemons, but limes are cheap and plentiful, so I used 4 good sized persian limes to make this recipe.  Otherwise, followed it exactly.  I have tried other lemon bars, but without success.  These are, in my humble opinion, perfect.  The crust is crunchy, sweet and tasty with real butter, and the filling, which goes together in minutes, is the perfect compliment, being custardy, tart and exactly the right proportion.  I thought that small bars would not be sufficient, but these are very rich and filling.  I shared them with several people who have never eaten anything like them before, and all were impressed.  Make these.  You will be happy.  To get more juice from your lemons or limes, toss them in the  microwave for about 20 seconds per normal sized fruits.  Not sure about key limes.

text:
I used a 9x13 nonstick pan and liked the thickness of the bars. Not everything needs to be super-sized. Added 1/4 tsp salt and 1 tsp lemon zest to the crust mixture. Baked 20 minutes at 325 using speed-convection. Cooled the crust completely in the refrigerator before filling step. For filling used 1/3 cup flour, 2/3 cup lemon juice, and 2 tsp zest. Used the full amout of sugar and bars were not overly sweet and had a nice tartness. Baked for 12 minutes at 325 speed-convection, then reduced temp to 300 for another 12 minutes. Heavily dusted with powdered sugar while still hot/warm, then cooled in the refrigerator overnight. Filling was nicely set like lemon curd jelly, and crust was crisp tender shortbread which did not crumble from slicing. Love this recipe!

text:
The 4 stars it's for the recipe as it's written.  Was very good, if you like a mellow tartness.  Having said that, if you are hoping for that "POW WOW" in your mouth, you have to modify! After reading some of the suggestions,  I decided to try it again using some of them.  I added to the crust mix about 1/8 to 1/4 tsp of salt.   Lemon juice, I used exactly 2/3 of a cup; added another 3 Tbsp of flour to the sugar and flour mix.  Blended, instead of whisking,  the lemon juice, 1 Tbs of lemon zest, and eggs first, then I added the flour and sugar and blended for just a few seconds ( I used the Vitamix) then poured onto the baked crust. It was a beautiful and delighful thing!!! much more tart, and even lemon dessert haters couldn't resist devouring them!!

text:
This is the first time I've tried to make lemon bars. Long time lover of them though. Based upon some of the reviews that the filling wasn't enough for the amount of crust this recipe makes, I tried another variation that worked out very well. I made the recipe as it is called out, with only one ingredient variation....I added more sugar to the crust. I then used a square 8x8 inch pan instead of the 9x13 one called for in the recipe. Because this made everything more dense, I increased the baking time for the crust by 5 mins and the filling baking time by 10 mins. By using a smaller pan, the amount of crust to the amount of filling was perfect! This gave me a slightly thicker crust and more dense filling to crust ratio. Perfection!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I consider this my "go-to" recipe for Lemon Bars!  I made them twice; the first time was as stated.  I found that there was not enough filling, and the filling was not tart enough for my family's liking. 

For my second batch I tweaked the ingredients for results that are more of our liking.  For my crust I used the ingredients as stated, also adding 3/4 teaspoon of salt.  For the filling I increased the quantity by "roughly" 50%.  I used 6 extra-large eggs,  2 1/4 cups of sugar, 1/2 cup of flour (doubled to compensate for the increased amount of lemon juice I used), 3/4 teaspoon of salt, and 1 1/4 cups of fresh lemon juice (we like them more "tart").  I recommend "fresh squeezed" lemon juice (include the pulp!) because the bottled stuff you buy just wouldn't be nearly as good!   If you don't like your lemon bars "tart", cut the lemon juice back to your liking.  If you do cut back on the lemon juice, be sure to decrease the amount of flour accordingly.  

Using a well-greased (I use Crisco) 9" x 13" baking pan (and I highly recommend you grease your pan, as these bars would certainly stick to the pan if you don't), I baked my crust for 17 minutes before adding the filling.   After removing the crust  from the oven I let it cool for 5 minutes.   I then added the filling and baked the bars for 26 minutes. 

I cooled mine to room temperature (about 2 hours), and then put them in the refrigerator for 4 hours to "firm up" before cutting.  They cut much better when they're cold.

Absolutely delicious! Bright, velvety lemon custard in a light, buttery shortbread crust - perfection. I made this in a 9" tart pan. Used about 3/4 of the custard and about 3/4 of crust. Saved the extra and made small tarts :) I followed other readers' recommendations and added a 1/4 tsp salt to crust, and in the custard used 2/3 cup lemon juice and 2 tbsp lemon zest with and extra 1/4 cup of flour. I baked both the crust and the filled pie for 20 min each. It popped right out of the tart pan and slightly d perfectly off the pan base into serving dish. I simply dusted too liberally with powdered sugar and garnished with lemon zest - so elegant and so easy!!

text:
The crust recipe is practically fool proof. I have made it twice now and perfect each time. I did allow for the crust to completely cool before adding the filling. I added zest of one lemon and measured out  a 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice and followed the recipe's remaining ingredient measurements and baked for about 30 minutes.  I thought I might have overbaked by a few minutes as the sides seemed to be browner than what was expected, but oh my gosh, the sides were the best part! The second time I let the filling bake for about 27 minutes and it was perfect. It gave me the freash bright lemony tang I was craving and when chilled the filling set very nicely. I am addicted to these and this recipe is really simple. I think adding the zest should be recommended as it really kicks up the P-Pow! on the flavor.

I love these Lemon Bars, they're so good!  I double the filling recipe and increase the lemon juice to 1 1/3 cups and the flour to 1 cup.  I make them in a 9x11 pan. I saw the suggestion not to make any substitutions with this recipe, but since I have dairy and gluten allergies, I always try my luck. This recipe turned out FANTASTICALLY with my subs. I used an AP Gluten Free flour mix (Bob's Red Mill Gluten Free 1 to 1 Baking Flour) and Earth Balance soy free spread and loved the results. I am absolutely saving this recipe for the future!

I loved this bar! I did follow some of the recommendations ie: I used  2/3 cup of fresh squeezed lemon juice and added 1 tbspn of flour and added 1/4 tsp of salt to the crust. I had to bake the crust 30ish minutes to get that golden brown colour I like and next time I make it, I will reduce the sugar in the crust by half. I found the crust a bit sweet for my liking. I will definitely make it again.

text:
Love this recipe!! I've made it many times, with a few minor changes:

1. I need to bake the crust for at least 30 minutes in order for it to become golden 

2. I make sure the crust has cooled completely BEFORE pouring in the lemon filling--the first time I made the mistake of pouring on the lemon filling right after the crust came out of the oven, and it was too soft and broke apart under the stream of lemon filling

3.  I add 1 tsp of lemon zest to the crust--gives it a delicious smell and taste!

4. Small pinch of salt in the crust and lemon filling enhances the flavors and decreases the sourness of the lemon a bit

text:
These lemon bars were AMAZING. I made little to no changes to this recipe. Many people were saying the crust was too tasteless, so I used salted butter instead, and the crust was perfect. it was sweet, crispy and had just the right amount of flavor. I also used four small lemons instead of two. The lemon was a little overpowering, but that was a fault on my part. I think 1/2 a cup of  lemon juice would be adequate. Other then these small tweaks, these bars were flavorful, chewy and delicious. I HIGHLY recommend this (almost) foolproof recipe for quick easy lemon bars. Like the name says, these were the best lemon bars I've ever had!

I haven't had lemon bars since I was younger. These bars came out just like my mom's. However I did change a few things. I used a 7x11 pan, making the crust and filling a little thicker. It was by no means room temp, it was still warm to the touch but not hot. The filling is lovely. I'm really happy with the consistency. 10/10 would make again.

I like this recipe however I made my own modifications - i have used less sugar in the custard (1 1/4 instead of 1 1/2 cups), and used more lemon juice. I have also added 1 teaspoons of lemon oil to add more flavor. I have also used cold butter instead of soft butter for the crust - i cut cold butter in cubes, added flour and sugar to the food processor and mixed it. Then I put this mix into a baking dish and slightly pressed it, not too much. It turned out lovely, my family liked it. I will do it again.

This is the only lemon bar recipe I use.  A few changes though- I found the crust to be too buttery for my taste, so I use a half a cup/stick of butter. I also use lemon juice and just pour a bunch in- I really like my lemon bars to actually taste like lemon, and not have a hint of it. I always make it the night before an event or have them chill over night, always ends up being much tastier the next day.

text:
This is a perfect recipe.  If you want to add some flavor to your crust change the sugar to dark brown sugar.  This will give it a more robust flavor.  You can also take half of the butter for the crust and brown it.  This gives it depth of flavor.  I also zested three lemons and used the juice from three lemons.  Add one teaspoon of flour to the lemon mix if you do this.  Your bars will be lemony and not stiff.

I also lined my pan with parchment to make the bars easy to take out.  Let them cool completely in the pan before removing them.

Three stars represents how I would rate this recipe without alterations. Luckily, however, I read previous comments, made some changes, and the bars turned out great! I add a pinch of salt to the crust. I needed 2/3 to 3/4 cups of lemon juice in the filling for the proportion of crust to filling to be right, otherwise the crust was too thick. text:
Excellent as everyone raves - easily the best crust I've ever tasted on a lemon bar.  I did add about a half teaspoon of kosher salt, per suggestions.  I mixed the crust in a food processor because forgot to take the butter out early which actually worked out well.  On the filling, didn't have any fresh lemons so substituted a 1/2 cup of bottled lemon juice.  The cooking times were spot on for my oven and it came out with excellent consistency. The bottled juice worked just fine but next time would use the real thing for the slightly fresher taste and might use about another half recipe of filling as prefer thicker lemon layer.  The crust thickness in a 9x13 pan is perfect at 1/2 inch but the great tasting lemon filling was only about 1/4 inch deep.  But this is definitely my future go-to recipe for a no fail result of lemony goodness. Thanks to the submitter and all those with helpful comments.

text:
I made the following changes based on the reviews I saw here:
-used a little over 1/2 cup lemon juice
-a tiny bit of salt to the crust

My own changes:
-only 1 cup sugar used for the lemon filling
-vanilla sugar added to lemon filling

I was scared to see how much sugar goes into this as I measured everything out. I decided to put less sugar in the filling, making it a lot more tarty. I thought this worked nicely because the crust was really sweet and buttery anyway. This was my first time making lemon bars and they came out great! Everyone loved them, and I already have requests to make more.

Very tasty, although personally I think they could have used a little more tartness and lemon zest. (Other people were fairly evenly split on whether they were perfect or needed more lemon.)  Following previous suggestions, I used 1/3 cup + 2 Tbsp. of lemon juice, added the zest of 1/2 lemon, and increased the flour to 1/3 cup, but next time I will add another 2 Tbsp of lemon juice and use the zest of an entire lemon.  However, the lemon layer did set beautifully (in contrast to other lemon bar recipes I have tried), and the crust was wonderfully rich-tasting--I used salted butter, which gave a lovely flavor.

text:
I've made these a couple times now and they're always a hit! I've dinked around a bit, and thought I'd report my findings. I make sure to use at least 1/3 cup lemon juice, with a tbsp extra of flour in the custard to compensate for the texture. I throw in the zest from one lemon. Before I juice, I make sure to microwave the lemons and roll them around on the counter for max yield! I wasn't a fan of adding salt to the crust - I thought it added a strange, unneeded flavor. Finally, when the bars are done (and probably better to undercook a tad than get them too chewy), I dust them very lightly with powered sugar. Overall, this is an excellent recipe that even non sweets fans can enjoy!

This was s disappointment.  I followed the recipe exactly, except I added the zest of the lemons to the crust and since my lemons were small I used three instead of two.  A measurement of juice would have been preferable, mine came out to be about 1/4 cup.  I used a food processor to make the crust and my butter was not very soft, but since I was using a food processor, I thought chilled butter would work better.  The pan was a non-stick heavy gauge 9x13 pan.  In general, the crust came out well, but a bit thick and too buttery, but the topping was waaaay too sweet and not enough lemon flavor.  It was a bit gummy too, not the light creamy lemony flavor I was desiring.  I did top it with powdered sugar for a nice looking finish.  I will be looking for a different recipe or adjusting this one.  Did I mention that there was too much sugar and not enough lemon flavor!!!!
