text:
I am a beginner of all beginners when it comes to baking, but this recipe was so easy to follow. I made some adjustments on my way and I'd like to share those. I put 3 oz of butter, 1 1/2 cup of flour and added a little less than 1 ts of salt for the crust. The crust looked a bit too dry when I first put it in the pan, but it turned out just fine. Next time I make this, I'll do everything just the same but put only 1/2 ts of salt. Also, I had the crust stay in the oven for 20 minutes and the filling for 30 minutes. After that, I let it cool in room temperature then in the fridge before I cut it. I made this for a potluck and everyone said the amount of butter, salt, and sugar was just perfect. One last thing, do not forget parchment paper! I had to cut it in the pan, which left some scratches on the bottom of the pan :(

The lemon mixture turned out far to runny, so I had to add sugar, flour, and finally, corn starch. The crust needed a bit more sugar so as to taste something else than butter. I recommend adding maybe and 1/8 cup of sugar to the crust, or even a 1/4. Than, add at least one more lemon to the lemon mixture, and maybe a tad more sugar. It definitely needs more lemons, though, because they're at least supposed to be lemony. I made lime bars with this recipe, and actually, they turned out better than I expected given the amount of changing I had to do with the recipe. So, overall, the recipe was okay. Oh, by the way, I highly recommend lime bars. Just replace lemons with the lime, and it tastes fantastic in a lemon bar recipe!

text:
This recipe is very similar to the one I use with a couple changes.  1) Use powdered sugar for the crust instead of regular sugar.  2) Use cold butter for the crust and cut it into the flour/sugar mix like you would for a pie crust (please do not use anything other than butter - yummy!) 3) IF you are looking for a quantity of fresh lemon juice (please use fresh, it's so much better than bottled) I use 5/8 C. 4) Add 2 t baking powder to lemon mixture - it makes the filling extra light and fluffy.  Be prepared for the raves, you will now be known for your lemon bars!

text:
I made these on a whim and realized too late into my preparation that I had no lemons, so I substituted with 5-1/2 Tablespoons of lemon juice and 1/2 teaspoon of lime juice. I also didn't have enough butter, so I used 1/2 c. margarine and 1/2 c. butter. In the end, these still turned out with delicious, buttery crust, and nice evenly sweet and tart topping, just like they should be! I have had bad luck with lemon bars in the past, so this time, I poured the lemon mixture onto the crust immediately after the crust was done, not letting the crust cool before returning it to the oven. I will definitely make these again, but with fresh fruit and all butter next time. Great recipe and so easy. Thank you for sharing!

text:
These were good, but not great - I know I've eaten (if not made) better Lemon Bars.
I did make this recipe exactly as written, except that it needed to be baked longer, about 22 minutes, until it seemed done.
I ate the whole batch over about a week, and they tasted pretty good, but the top layer seemed a little odd - maybe too many eggs? One thing that wasn't elaborated on, in preparing the bottom (crust) layer, was using a pastry blender. Were I a beginner, I wouldn't have know about it, but I worked the pastry blender, and firmly pressed the crust, and I really thought that the crust was deserving of "The Best" title; it's just that the top layer needs a little tweaking.

text:
i would only give this a 3 cause the crust is way to thick. I like my lemon filling to be thicker than the crust and the crust was way too thick. I think the recipe is a great one but just needs some tweeking. I would half the crust recipe and add pinch of salt to it. Also the baking time on the crust was way to long. I would cook 12 mins or less. Mine was way over cooked once i cooked the filling. I was kind of bummed it didn't turn out perfect the first time. Next time i will make adjustments. * and extra twist mix one softened cream cheese w 1/2 c sugar 1tsp vanilla and one egg. Pour over crust and than pour over the filling over that. The cream cheese will rise to the top. maybe add an extra 5-10 mins for baking.

Excellent! However, I did do a substitution- I had about 1/2 lard on hand that needed to be used up, so I cut that in with 1/2 c. butter, and added about 1/2 tsp. salt to the crust- YUM! As other reviewers recommended, added some bottled lemon juice to the mix, as I only had about 1/3 c. fresh to get a little over 1/2 c. juice, and threw in the zest, as well. Also added a tiny amount of vanilla and almond extracts to wet mixture (because I can't resist doing that sort of thing!) Wonderful crust-to-topping ratio, and my MIL and sons were delighted with the bars. (And three bars later, so am I!) Might try making the recipe as written next time, LOL! Really good bars. Thank you, Patty Schenck!

text:
The crust on mine is like shortbread held together nicely. The lemon flavor is going to depend on your lemons. All lemons are not created equal, I just juiced 4 and had a cup of juice. I have had lemons with very little flavor. Hint, check out you lemon by taste tart & sour = great. Lack flavor without pucker either need more or new ones. You could probably use the plastic lemon for flavor, but to me it has a funky taste. My next batch is in the oven for friends by special requests. 
I did not tweak or change anything. If everyone loved it why fix it if it isn't broke. This is a keeper as is.

The crust was too crumbly and not golden and the filling was barely sufficient to fill the 9x9 pan. I find that this lack of filling problem occurs with ALL the lemon bar recipes I've tried. I also didn't dust the top with powdered sugar, because my family isn't huge on sugar.
Nonetheless, it was pretty good, just not the crust, and the filling was a tad too sour. If there's a next time, I'll use 1 cup sugar for the filling, make 50% more filling, and add more butter in the crust.

text:
Simple ingredients and a really nice outcome. Based on suggestions I made a few adjustments. CRUST: I used only about 2/3 of the crust in a smaller casserole dish (1/4 -1/3 inch thick). Make sure to really get the crust golden otherwise it won't hold together well. I also used my hands to mix the crust and kneaded it like pie dough to create "streaks" of butter/flour to increase flakiness. CUSTARD: I used a little more than 1/2 cup fresh lemon juice & the zest of 2 lemons to really boost the pucker factor. Because I used a smaller dish I had to cook it a bit longer. With less crust & thicker lemon custard they're very gooey but they got rave reviews from family & coworkers.  I my cut a little sugar out next time - even with the added lemons they were too sweet for my taste. Also- don't use Meyer lemons. I tried this before with Meyers and the result was not tart. Meyer lemons are an orange hybrid and much less tangy than a regular lemon.

text:
tastes really nice :) But i did make a few changes. First off, i added 30 gms of flour to the crust and took 10 gms of sugar off the original measurement :) after forming the "crust", i chilled it for around 30 minutes before popping it in the oven. Once the crust was done, I poured hald the egg/lemon mixture and baked it for 5 minutes then added the remaining half after. I also prolonged the baking time to around 5-10 mins :D went out pretty firm :D I suggest you adjust the amount of lemon juice to your preference. If you want it lemony tarty then add more lemon but if you dont then just lessen the amount of lemon :)

I used an 8 by 13 baking pan for this :)

text:
These are TO. DIE. FOR. I used the zest and juice of three large lemons (1/2 cup juice). This is a must for tangy lemony filling. Please juice fresh lemons, people; don't use the concentrate! It makes ALL the difference. I also added 1/2 teaspoon salt to the filling. I baked in a slightly smaller pan (23 minutes for crust and then another 23 for filling). I did not cool the crust before pouring the filling on. The only complaint is that I think the taste of the crust is a little overpowering - it's very buttery, and you can taste it more than the lemony filling. Next time, I would make the crust thinner.

Hey all, especially Patty. I've been meaning to write this and get your feedback but I thought I could solve it on my own.

Mine is a strange story. I got the amounts (not proportions) wrong as I was using a measuring cup that was = 2.5 cups and not 1 cup.

It turned out perfect but I had double the crust -no biggie. The filling was white and translucent and oozing. The icing sugar topping didn't melt and the crust was crispy and biscuit-like. All in all, a wonderful 1st try.

My 2nd attempt was horrible and the filling came out too eggy even though I added only 1 more egg.

I then realised that I could get the measurements in metric (I'm stupid like that) but I tried to proceed with what I thought was my wrong measurements, in metric this time and the next 3 or 4 attempts came up bad, especially the crust.

I went back to Patty's original recipe in metric and it turned out good except that the crust wasn't crispy around the edges and the filling wasn't oozy and was yellow.

My question is this, how do I get the same results as my 1st time? I really loved it then! Somehow, the filling wasn't yellow and the consistency was fantastic (though a little too sweet).

I've done this 8 times now and I can't get it back even by following the recipe to the letter! I especially need to get the crust crispy all round again!

OMG, please help!!!!

This was my first time making lemon bars at all, let alone from sratch, but think this recipe will need some TLC if I try it again. 

The flavor wasn't bad, although a bit too sweet and tart (reminscent of lemonhead candy). Tasted like a condensed filling. Was difficult to manage cutting (I refrigerated first) and spreads very thin (used a small nonstick rectange pan 11x7 I think). Also the crust was a little lack-luster IMO. 

My grandmother had the best lemon bars in the world. They're what I compare all others to, but couldn't find her recipe so I found this one. If I find hers I'll probably figure out where this one falls a bit short for me.

text:
We LOVED this... and I did not alter the recipe - I usually like to try it as written first, then I can tweak it next time if necessary.  I halved the recipe and divided it between 8 ramekins.  (I make desserts in ramekins primarily so I don't eat too much... but in this case, I think I ended up eating 4 of them over the course of a couple days.  Ha!)  The amount of crust vs. filling was perfect for me.  I thought I would need more filling, but it puffs up a little bit during baking, and ended up being just right.  Don't judge it too soon!  Since I didn't have lemons and had to use lemon juice, I did take the advice of a few others and used slightly more than what I think 2 lemons would've produced.  I used 3/8 of a cup for HALF a recipe - so 2/3 if you made the full recipe.  Yum!  Don't bother buying the box mixes.  This is super simple, and super yum!

I tried out this recipe because I seem to have temporarily lost my favorite recipe in our recent move and I saw all the great reviews. I was a little nervous when I saw some of the comments associated with the lower-rated reviews on this recipe (lack of lemon taste, mushy, not setting properly, etc) AFTER I had them baking in the oven!  I pulled them from the oven and tasted them right away while they were still hot just to reassure myself I wasn't going to be disappointed after they cooled and they were wonderful!  Now, crust is one of my favorite parts and I love the chewy edges of the lemon filling and this had both.  Maybe it's just a difference in tastes but I can't see how anybody could be disappointed with these bars unless they didn't follow the recipe exactly.  The kids didn't even wait for them to be all the way cooled and they were gone!

text:
I have made lemon bars every year at holiday time, trying a new recipe each year with little success, that is until this year, with this recipe.  Most other years my bars are over-done around the edges and under-done in the middle.  One year we ate the "bars" with a spoon.  This recipe was fantastic, perfectly done all over.  I quess I had super large lemons, because I ended up with 3/4 cup lemon juice.  I did not adjust the flour for the filling, and still these came out perfect.  The only change I would make next time is to increase the sugar in the filling a little, or decrease the lemon juice to 1/2 cup.  The larger amount of lemon juice made these a tad too tart for my husband's taste.  
I'm so glad I finally found a recipe and I can now toss out all the others I have accummulated over the years.  Thanks for the wonderful recipe.

My first attempt at lemon bars... and it was a complete disaster!  The only thing I can think of that might have turned this ugly is the use of parchment paper under the crust in a glass Pyrex baking dish.  In the middle of baking, I checked on them to make sure they weren't getting too brown.... and the crust had floated to the top!  The parchment was somewhere in the middle, with lemon filling above and below it.  What a waste and what a a mess!  I did cook it through, just in case it could be salvaged, but it was a goner.  I tasted a small piece minus the paper, and it would have been great had the crust stayed where it was supposed to....

text:
These are VERY good and I am a very picky cook! I did cheat a little, and made a couple of changes. First, I used a pie crust mix and added some sugar to it, then pressed into a pie plate and baked. I used butter-flavored cooking spray on the pie plate. I used bottled lemon juice, and added extra, so it came to about 1/2 cup. Now, we love lemon flavor. For those who don't like the sweet tart, don't use extra lemon. I baked for closer to 25 minutes, let cool, and then dusted with powdered sugar before cutting. Keep in mind that these really need to be stored in the refrigerator. They are fabulous! Hubby and kids loved them and so did I! This recipe is a keeper!

I am impressed! I added 1/4 tsp. of salt to the crust as suggested by other members. I also added 1 tsp. lemon zest (from a jar) and some yellow food coloring to the filling. I used 1/2 cup of fresh lemon juice, and it was a little bit too tart for me. Next time, I'll try using 1/3 cup. The crust was beautiful. The bars were even better after they were refrigerated. My husband loved them so much, he wants to eat them for breakfast!
